com.qualitascorpus.testsupport

Interface IO


  • public interface IO
    Provides an alternative (and very much more limited) interface for reading from standard input and writing to standard output. Any variables of this type should be used similar to how System.in or System.out would be used (albeit with much less functionality). Any application can use this interface for its input/output. If so, then such applications can also be subject to automated testing by substituting in a mock implementation for the usual implementation of this interface.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void print(java.lang.String str)
      Print to the standard output (typically the console) without a newline.
      void println(java.lang.String str)
      Print to the standard output (typically the console) with a newline.
      java.lang.String readFromKeyboard(java.lang.String prompt)
      Ask for input from standard input (typically the keyboard), displaying the specified prompt to standard output.
      int readInteger(java.lang.String prompt, int lower, int upper, int cancelResult, java.lang.String cancelStr)
      Ask for an integer input from the standard input (typically the keyboard), displaying the specified prompt plus the cancelStr to the current output location, and requiring that the input be from the range [lower..upper].

    • Method Detail

      • readFromKeyboard

        java.lang.String readFromKeyboard(java.lang.String prompt)
        Ask for input from standard input (typically the keyboard), displaying the specified prompt to standard output. Example 
             ...
     String suppliedInput = io.readFromKeyboard("Enter one of 'yes' or 'no' please"); // io is of type IO
     // At this point the variable suppliedInput has whatever value was supplied from 
     // standard input
        Returns:
        A string as supplied from the standard input.

      • readInteger

        int readInteger(java.lang.String prompt,
              int lower,
              int upper,
              int cancelResult,
              java.lang.String cancelStr)
        Ask for an integer input from the standard input (typically the keyboard), displaying the specified prompt plus the cancelStr to the current output location, and requiring that the input be from the range [lower..upper]. If the supplied input matches the cancelStr, then the value cancelResult will be returned. If the supplied input is not in the required range, the request for input will be repeated. Example: 
             ...
     int suppliedInput = io.readInteger("Enter a number between 1 and 20", 1, 20, -1, "no"); // io is of type IO
     // If what was supplied from standard input was "no", then the variable suppliedInput will have
     // the value -1, otherwise it will have a value between 1 and 20.
        Parameters:
        prompt - What message to display when requesting the integer input
        lower - The lower bound of the range (inclusive)
        upper - The upper bound of the range (inclusive)
        cancelResult - What value to return if the attempt at input is cancelled
        cancelStr - What string the user should enter to cancel the input
        Returns:
        Either cancelResult or an integer in the range [lower..upper] (inclusive).

      • print

        void print(java.lang.String str)
        Print to the standard output (typically the console) without a newline.

      • println

        void println(java.lang.String str)
        Print to the standard output (typically the console) with a newline.
